body: The Big Question

If you’re within this piece’s creators age range *cough* mid-20s to mid-30s *cough*, chances are you have been asked by parents or nosy older relatives that tiresome question “When are you getting married?” - whether you’re men, women, or non-binary.
Being foreign residents ourselves, we decided to take a look at inter-ethnic marriages within the last four decades in Singapore.
When Do People Get Married?
Now they may ask you the marriage question at any eligible age, but when do Singaporeans typically get married?

Based on findings from the Department of Statistics, for this decade’s (2010 to 2017) citizens and residents, the median age for women was 28 years old and men at 30.1 years old for their first marriage. Compare this with the 1980s (1984 to 1989) when women’s median age was 24.6 years old and men at 27.3 years old.

In general, men get married at an older age than women. The median age of first marriage for both men and women rose by at least one year per decade since the 1980s up to the 2010s, indicating a trend of current Singaporeans preferring to make the commitment later than others did in the past.
Number of Marriages in Singapore

There has been a steady increase in the number of inter-ethnic marriages in Singapore from 1980 to 2018. There was a 55.2 percent increase from the previous decade (2000 to 2009) to this decade (2010 to 2018).
Total number of marriages within the present decade (2010 to 2018) under the Women’s Charter was 198,278.
Out of those marriages there were 35,370 (17.8 percent) inter-ethnic marriages.
These are the six ethnic groups that combine to form inter-ethnic marriages in Singapore:

<mark class='caucasian'>Caucasian</mark> (8,797 individuals in 2010s)
<mark class='chinese'>Chinese</mark> (28,020 individuals in 2010s)
<mark class='eurasian'>Eurasian</mark> (1,686 individuals in 2010s)
<mark class='indian'>Indian</mark> (5,237 individuals in 2010s)
<mark class='malay'>Malay</mark> (1,782 individuals in 2010s)
<mark class='other'>Other</mark> (25,218 individuals in 2010s)
By ethnicity, the <mark class='chinese'>Chinese</mark> made up for the most numbers with 28,020 individuals entering inter-ethnic marriages in the present decade.
Out of the total 35,370 inter-ethnic marriages, there was a majority of 18,527 <mark class='chinese'>Chinese grooms</mark> looking for love among brides of the other five ethnicities.

The most popular pairing thus involved <mark class='other'>Other brides</mark> and <mark class='chinese'>Chinese grooms</mark>, making up 17,182 (48.6 percent) inter-ethnic marriages in the present decade.
The Answer for the Future
One dares to say that we have more open attitudes in Singapore when it comes to finding the one than they had in the past.
Rather than a melting pot, Singapore claims itself as a salad bowl where each of us retains our identities while still mixing to form the island’s colourful culture.
Here’s hoping that opening Singapore’s borders continues to lead to open minds.

Data and Method
We looked at a few marriage-related data from the 1980s to the 2010s under the Women's Charter in Singapore.
We summed up the numbers in each decade from 1980 to 2018 for comparison. We discovered that there has been a rise in inter-ethnic marriages despite the fluctuation in the number of total marriages.
Source: Data.gov.sg, Singapore Department of Statistics
